title: FIRE Calculator (Financial Independence)

seo.title: FIRE Calculator | When Can I Retire Early?
seo.description: Calculate your 'Financial Independence, Retire Early' date. Input your savings rate and expenses to find your FI Number and escape the rat race.

summary: Join the FIRE movement. Calculate exactly how much money you need to never work again, and when you can clock out for the last time.

faq.a: The 4% Rule is a guideline stating you can withdraw 4% of your portfolio in the first year of retirement (adjusted for inflation thereafter) and have a high probability of not running out of money for 30 years.

Your Financial Independence Number is 25 times your annual expenses (assuming a 4% withdrawal rate). If you spend $40,000/year, your FI Number is $1,000,000. Once you hit this number, work becomes optional.
This is a gross estimator. You should input 'Annual Expenses' that include your estimated tax liability in retirement. If you plan to spend $40k on lifestyle and owe $5k in taxes, input $45k.

Lean FIRE is retiring on a bare-bones budget (e.g., <$30k/year). Fat FIRE is retiring with a luxurious budget (e.g., >$100k/year). This calculator works for bothâ€”just adjust the 'Annual Expenses' input.

article.heading: The Math of Freedom
article.body:
The standard advice is 'save 10% of your income and retire at 65'. The FIRE (Financial Independence, Retire Early) movement rejects this. By saving 50% or more of your income, you can compress 40 years of saving into 10-15 years.

**The equation is simple:**
*   Higher Savings Rate = Faster Freedom
*   Lower Expenses = Lower FI Number

If you save 0% of your income, you can never retire. If you save 100% of your income (living for free), you can retire today.

article.heading: Calculating Your Number
article.body:
To retire, your assets must generate enough passive income to cover your bills. 

**The Rule of 25:**
`Annual Expenses x 25 = FI Number`

If you spend $50,000 a year, you need $1.25 million invested. At a 4% withdrawal rate ($1.25M x 0.04), your portfolio generates the $50,000 you need. 

*Note: This assumes your portfolio grows at ~7% and inflation is ~3%, leaving you with a 4% 'safe' withdrawal.*

article.heading: Variables to Watch
article.body:
1.  **Savings Rate:** This is the most powerful lever. Increasing your savings rate from 10% to 50% cuts your working career by decades.
2.  **Investment Return:** We default to 7% (historical stock market average after inflation). Be careful assuming higher returns.
3.  **Withdrawal Rate:** Conservative investors prefer a 3.5% or 3% withdrawal rate to be safe, which requires a larger portfolio (33x expenses).
